utterances: Outside observers have been clamoring for the president to appoint someone with both management and technology chops to oversee the website full time.
Former White House advisor Ezekiel Emanuel says Kurt DelBene, who used to run Microsoft's Office division fits that bill.
Now, they're bringing in someone with a lot of IT experience and certainly management experience.
It looks like we're going in the right direction.
DelBene, who is married to a freshman congresswoman from Washington State, has agreed to stay on the job for at least six months.
Emanuel says that continuity is important.
You don't put Google up and walk away.
You don't put Facebook up and walk away.
These things need constant attention, constant upgrading and constant tweaking to ensure that the user experience is optimized.
At the White House today, the president also quizzed high tech CEOs about how the government can use technology more effectively in areas like healthcare.
Obama told a Wall Street Journal conference last month the list of failed government computer projects goes way beyond healthcare.gov.
There's probably no bigger gap between the private sector and the public sector than IT.
The troubled launch of the insurance website has hurt not only the president's own political standing, but that of his fellow Democrats as well.
New Hampshire Senator Jeanne Shaheen praised the White House this afternoon for trying to make things right.
We're going to run into these kinds of obstacles, but the point is not to give up, to try and fix whatever is not working and to make it better.
Employees from Microsoft, Google, and other high tech firms have been among the president's top contributors.
But many high tech companies are angry about the administration's electronic surveillance efforts, which sometimes put them in the awkward position of handing over customers records.
Last week, companies ran a full-page newspaper ad complaining about the spying.

White House spokesman Jay Carney says today's meeting with the CEOs was also a chance to hear those executives concerns and to explain the administration's own effort to balance its surveillance methods.
Making sure that we're doing what we can and should to keep ourselves safe and not just what we can because we have the technological capacity to do it.
The White House is expected to complete its own review of spying methods next month.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, the White House.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Audie Cornish.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
If you thought the presidential primaries were remarkably negative, well, statistical evidence now says you're right.
A new analysis of TV ad finds that 70 percent of the messages were negative.
NPR's Peter Overby reports that behind that number was a crowd of heavily-finance superPACs throwing elbows on behalf their candidates.
Now that Mitt Romney has locked up the Republican nomination, the pro-Romney superPAC, Restore Our Future, is on the air with a positive that it's used before.
It's a story of how a 1996, Romney helped to find the missing daughter of a former colleague, Robert Gay.
(SOUNDBITE OF A POLITICAL AD)
Romney put his employees to work on the search in New York City.
The girl was found in a suburban town a few days later.
That ad is a rare bright spot in a campaign marked by snarling attacks and sneering contrasts.
Seventy percent of the presidential ads have been negative this cycle, versus 91 percent positive at this point in the 2008 election.
That's the new analysis from the Wesleyan Media Project, which examines political ads on broadcast TV and national cable.
The raw data come from Kantar Media.
One of the Wesleyan Project's co-director is Erika Franklin Fowler, a political scientist at Wesleyan University in Connecticut.
She says that at this point in the 2008 cycle, 97 percent of the ads came from candidates.
But this cycle...
Sixty percent of all ads are sponsored by interest groups, which is really, truly a historic number.
The shift follows the Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United ruling and a subsequent lower court ruling which encouraged outside groups to plunge into the presidential contest.
Fowler says that for the candidate it's worked out great.
For playing the puzzle today, you get a WEEKEND EDITION lapel pin.
You also get puzzle books and games.
You can read all about it at our website, npr.org/puzzle.
And before we let you go, Dan, what is your public radio station?
Right.
And we actually see this kind of modification of reality quite often.
The question is, are you doing it because you're achievement-motivated, that you want to a future for yourself, or is this something about managing impressions?

To the extent that you're being boastful in remembering a SAT score that's higher than you actually achieved and you were using this to impress others, well, we don't see that as a type of implicit goal setting.
But if you were...
Well, I'm not to going to go back and retake the SAT.
Exactly.
I might do worse!

So to the extent that something is modifiable, like a GPA for students who are still in school, or when you are on a diet and you told your friend that you lost five pounds but you only lost three, the idea is maybe that next week you step up the diet, you exercise a little bit more because you just committed to saying to somebody, you know, I lost five pounds, and now you have a new goal that you are trying to achieve.
Here's an email we got from JKL in Florida.
I have a friend who exaggerates in conversation.
I presume the reason is for dramatic effect and to seem more interesting than she really is.
Well, it was interesting at first, but when we realize it's an exaggeration, if not an actual lie, it becomes irritating.
How can we, her friends, handle this?

Well, perhaps hooking her up to a lie detector will be a good start, but yeah, there is a distinction, I think, your study found, between, well, people who - this slight exaggeration and people who are posers.
Right, exactly.
And when you are doing it to impress somebody, to make others think better of you, well, this isn't the type of exaggeration that we see associated with improvement.
It's the subtle, I want to be better so let me tell you, I think I got a B in science, but they probably got a B-minus.
The next science class, the idea is that they try a little bit harder.
That was where they want to be as opposed to where they actually were.
And I wonder, you said that they would round up their - round up, exaggerate their GPA, their grade point average, by as much as half a point or so.
Would they break through the psychological barrier of saying, you know, if your GPA was 2.8, would they take it over 3?
If your GPA was, you know, three and a half, would they take it to four?
Well, they exaggerated - the exaggerations are small but systematic.
So if they are just inaccurate, one could say, oh, I don't really remember my exact GPA.
Well, then you'd expect people to make errors on both sides, that they would underestimate their GPA as well as overestimate, and that is not what happens.
About half of the people systematically overestimate.
But they're doing it at small dosages, that half a point.
So in your example, maybe a 2.8 going up to a 3.1 or a 3.2.
So not flagrant lies.
Again, not something out of whole cloth, but just a slight indication that this is where they'd like to be, and then ultimately they achieve that goal.
And in that circumstance, they seem to be entirely uncomfortable with it and at least according to the equipment you've got, they don't perceive it as a lie.
Right, that's what was remarkable.
People were exaggerating and they were motivated to do this out of a defensive stance that I should be a 3.5, even though I'm not.
We'd expect much more distress and tension.

If it was an exaggeration that's reflecting this intrinsic goal, this positive illusion that this is where we want to be, a future-oriented self, then we expect people to be more clam and composed in both the physiological equipment and when we had independent observers watch the videotape.
The people who exaggerated actually appeared the most calm and composed.
(Soundbite of laughter)
All right.
So when everybody is the most - the calmest person in the world is piping it.
Anyway, let's talk with Jack.
Jack's calling us from Fresno in California.
JACK (Caller) Yes, hi.
I just wanted to say that I'm not so much an exaggerator as an out-and-out liar.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But it's more for my entertainment and the entertainment of others because sometimes the truth just isn't as interesting.
Can you give us an example of an entertaining lie, Jack?
Well, OK.
Well, I was once - I am a musician.

I was on tour and I happened to come to this intersection and this gentleman nearly cuts me off, we had this near head-on collision, we show each other our fingers and then he turns, he gets out of his car, he's coming towards me.
The truth is, I just drove away, but what I tell my friends is that, well, I'm in my car and he's much bigger than me so I start chasing him around, which I thought was a funny story.
But the thing is I come from a long line of liars.
We kind of lie the way most people breath.
My sister once posed as a lawyer in the state of Texas to get my dad out of a court date so he could come to my other sister's wedding.
We don't call that a lie, I think we call that a felony.
(Soundbite of laughter)

I think that is just a great example of an exaggeration or a lie that's really about impressing others, being boastful, as opposed to, you know, he ultimately wants to be able to beat up the guy who chased him down.
Jack, good luck in your next cutoff on the freeway.
Thank you.
So long.
Bye, Jack.
